title: Self Introduction
objectives: Learn how to introduce yourself in Korean
Practice saying your name and nationality
Use basic sentence structures for self-introduction
context: In Korean culture, proper introductions are important! You'll often introduce yourself by name, then add information about where you're from.
The word order is different from English: 'I + name + am' becomes '저는 [name]이에요/예요' (jeoneun [name]ieyo/yeyo).
Let's learn the essentials for introducing yourself in any situation!
explanation: 저 (jeo) is the polite form of 'I/me'. In casual speech, you'd use 나 (na), but 저 is safer for introductions.
는 (neun) is a topic particle that follows nouns. 저는 (jeoneun) means 'As for me...' or simply 'I'.
이에요 vs 예요: Use 이에요 after words ending in consonants (데이비드이에요), use 예요 after vowels (사라예요).
입니다 (imnida) is more formal than 이에요/예요. Use it in professional settings or formal situations.
제 (je) is possessive 'my'. It's 저 + 의 combined. So 제 이름 = 'my name'.
Countries: 미국 (America), 한국 (Korea), 중국 (China), 일본 (Japan), 영국 (England).
Add 사람 (saram = person) after country names to say nationality: 미국 사람 = American person.
